subject: Gardening
title: Seed Coats: Nature's Armor
description: A short lesson to help you apply Seed Coats: Nature's Armor.

hook.text: Some seeds survive being eaten, boiled, frozen, and even fired through a shotgun. Their armor is that good.

buildup.text: The seed coat (testa) protects against physical damage, pathogens, UV radiation, and premature water absorption.

discovery.text: Lotus seeds from a dry lakebed germinated after 1,300 years. Their thick coats kept them viable for a millennium.

twist.text: Some seeds need their coat damaged to germinateâ€”a process called scarification. Without scratching.

climax.text: The seed coat balances two opposing needs: protect the seed long enough, but open at exactly the right moment.

punchline.text: 1,300-year-old lotus seeds still germinate. That's armor.

quiz.question: What is scarification in seed science?
options: Removing the embryo from a seed for laboratory analysis
Damaging the seed coat to allow water in and trigger germination
Applying fertilizer directly to seed surfaces before planting
